By 2030, global demand for steel scrap is projected to hit¬†778 million tons, marking a¬†15.1% increase¬†compared to 2021, according to the POSCO Research Institute, as reported by S&P Global.

This growth underscores a clear trend: the world is not only consuming more scrap but also demanding¬†higher-quality raw materials. As the steel industry moves toward sustainable practices, electric arc furnaces are becoming central to expansion plans, while countries like¬†China¬†are raising the bar on quality standards for imported materials.

Looking further ahead, scrap demand is expected to reach¬†964 million tons by 2050¬†‚Äì a milestone aligned with global steel producers‚Äò ambitions for¬†carbon neutrality.

üåç Driving the Green Steel Cycle with LINDEMANN ‚ôªÔ∏è

The steel industry is stepping up by replacing old blast furnaces with electric arc furnaces, slashing CO2 by up to 80%.

All LINDEMANN machines are equipped with the quality and technology required for steel processing in compliance with the green steel cycle. From the material preparation of the scrap, separation of the fractions and the proven reduction of emissions right up to the result analysis which evaluates the purity level of the processed material: LINDEMANN is committed to the green steel cycle.

Instead of discarding components at the end of their ‚Äòfirst life‚Äô, we refurbish them to as-new condition. This ‚Äòsecond life‚Äô conserves raw materials, while the process requires only a fraction of the energy needed to manufacturing components from scratch. 

We are also working to reduce indirect emissions that occur along our value chain, by selecting suppliers that share our environmental goals. 

At LINDEMANN, we‚Äôre fueling the green transformation. Solutions like our 400 bar hydraulic technology, Variable Frequency Drive (VFD), and Shredder Drive Assistant (SDA), are designed to make recycling smarter, cleaner, and more efficient. We‚Äôre reducing emissions, optimizing energy use, and giving scrap a new life in the steel cycle.

The future of steel is green ‚Äì and it‚Äôs happening now. üîÑüíö

From D√ºsseldorf to Texas ‚Äì A Legacy Forged in Steel
It all began in 1913, when LINDEMANN launched its first baler press in D√ºsseldorf. What followed was more than a century of innovation, engineering excellence, and a growing global footprint.
One of the defining milestones came in 1958, when LINDEMANN delivered the world‚Äôs first hydraulically operated scrap shear ‚Äì a 1,200-ton powerhouse ‚Äì to Luria Brothers, then the largest scrap company in the United States.
Developed in cooperation with Lake Erie, a hydraulics company based in Buffalo, this groundbreaking machine marked the beginning of the hydraulic scrap shear era in North America. Many more followed, helping shape an entire industry.
Fast forward to the early 1980s, when the next chapter began:
The story of Texas Shredder took off in San Antonio, Texas, starting with spare parts and consumables for shredders. By 1986, the first Texas Shredder was delivered to Southern Iron & Metal in Beaumont, TX.
Since then, nearly 120 shredders have been built and installed‚Äîmost of them in North America‚Äîsolidifying the Texas Shredder name as a symbol of heavy-duty reliability.
Today, that legacy continues in products like the TXS 69x90 modular shredder, combining decades of proven experience with the smart performance needed for tomorrow‚Äôs scrap processing.
From D√ºsseldorf to Texas ‚Äì and far beyond ‚Äì LINDEMANN continues to shape the future of metal recycling with deep roots, bold ideas, and strong customer partnerships.
üåç Global roots. Local impact. Timeless engineering.

Did you know? üîÑ
Europe‚Äôs steel industry is undergoing a circular transformation ‚Äì and scrap metal is now considered a strategic resource.

Did you know? Aluminum is a true recycling champion.

Why Aluminium:

‚ôªÔ∏è Aluminum is infinitely recyclable ‚Äì without losing quality.
üîÅ 75% of all aluminum ever produced is still in use today.
‚ö° Using aluminum scrap instead of primary aluminum saves 95% of the energy.
üí° That‚Äôs up to 14,000 kWh saved per ton of recycled aluminum.
‚ö†Ô∏è Producing 1 ton of primary aluminum requires around 13.5 MWh of electricity.
‚úÖ Recycling needs just 0.67 MWh ‚Äì only 5% of the energy.
üå± The environmental impact? Aluminum scrap reduces CO‚ÇÇ emissions by 92% compared to primary production.
üìä Globally, the production of secondary aluminum is now twice as high as that of primary aluminum.
‚úÖ The result:
Aluminum scrap is no longer just waste ‚Äì it‚Äôs the most important raw material for aluminum production.

Fire protection for metal shredders ‚Äì before it gets critical.

Unmanned industrial shredders generate intense friction heat. Combined with combustible materials and limited human intervention, this creates a high fire risk. Especially in remote or dusty environments, fires can spread unnoticed ‚Äì threatening people, machines, and production uptime.
Our fixed-mounted thermal camera ensures continuous condition monitoring and early fire detection. Even in dust, heat, or haze, you stay in full control. Temperature developments are tracked in real time ‚Äì allowing automated responses and early warnings before danger escalates.
Smart safety, built-in. üî•

#MetalRecycling #FirePrevention #IndustrialSafety #ThermalCamera #ShredderProtection #LINDEMANN #ProcessMonitoring #MetalShredders #SmartSafety #RecyclingTechnology

Today marks the anniversary of the February 6 earthquake, and

Today marks the anniversary of the February 6 earthquake, and we remember with respect and compassion those who lost their lives. We extend our deepest condolences to their families and wish them strength and resilience. The pain of this great disaster remains in our hearts, reminding us once again of the importance of unity and solidarity.

Facing the reality of earthquakes and taking necessary precautions is crucial to preventing similar tragedies in the future. We must continue to raise awareness, be prepared for disasters, and take the necessary measures to ensure a safer tomorrow.

Today is not only a day of remembrance for those we lost but also a day to reflect, learn, and commit to building a safer future.

As part of our ongoing commitment to innovation, Aymas has consistently delivered top-quality and technologically advanced solutions over the years. One significant improvement introduced six years ago is the use of HUNGER brand seal housings in our guided guillotine shearing systems. This enhancement effectively prevents scratches caused by gaps between the shearing blades. As a result, we have statistically increased the operational lifespan of our cylinders by 140%.

üá¨üáß Jebb Metals have now put to work their new Koloss 1000 TS. This Lefort shear/baler is proving to be a real head turner as it sits proudly at the top of their yard. 

üí• Delivered to site in three main pieces the machine is assembled on a foundation frame and commissioned within two weeks. The machine is very productive on all grades of ferrous and non-ferrous metals, shearing with the 1000T window crosshead or baling with the 180T baling ram. 

üí™üèΩ The power, strength and speed of its cutting is giving very pleasing results for its new owners. This machine, fitted with the 600HP Scania diesel engine, operators control cabin and tunnel pusher ram is easily capable of 25-30 Tonnes per hour of production, depending upon material and cut length. 

We wish Philip & Stephen all the best for the future with their new Lefort Koloss 1000 TS üôå

üí•üé¨ [ùêØùê¢ùêùùêûùê®] bornesrecyclage  ramps-up with a new Lidex 1300T !

¬´¬†Our Lidex can go up to 70t/hr. It has a rail breaker and can handle heavy scrap when needed. In the crane, thanks to the automatic cycle, our operator can prepare the next load while the scrap previously loaded is still being processed. No time is lost !¬†¬ª Charles Bornes 

M. Bornes also prizes the total cooperation shown throughout the project including the recommendations for the most efficient layout of the machine on site, the supply of the civil engineering guide drawings, the logistic operations, the assembly & commissioning of the machine, not forgetting the training of operators and technicians.

Erg√§nzend wurden Grundlagen der Kommunikation und praxisnahe Modelle vermittelt.

Der zweite Teil vertiefte Themen wie Gespr√§chsf√ºhrung, Teamarbeit und Wirtschaft. Im Modul ‚ÄûFragen √ºber Fragen‚Äú lernten die Teilnehmenden gezieltes Fragenstellen. Die wirtschaftlichen Inhalte ‚Äì von der Geschichte des Geldes √ºber Bankwesen bis hin zu Versicherungen ‚Äì gaben wichtige Impulse f√ºr den verantwortungsvollen Umgang mit Finanzen.

Cars,
Metal,
Metal scrap.

Restoration of historic SENNEBOGEN machines - former apprentice project with a success story üîß
Our employees Andreas and Alois started their career at SENNEBOGEN with an extraordinary project: the restoration of historical machines for the opening of the Erich Sennebogen Museum in 2014. ‚ú® 
One of these machines was a SENNEBOGEN S 802 rope excavator, in production between 1958 and 1960. After so many decades, the wear and tear of time had taken a heavy toll on the machine, which had to be dismantled and painstakingly restored. Alongside other historical models, all restored to their former glory, it is a witness to the development of mechanical engineering in our company's history. üëè
Ten years after the museum opened, Andreas and Alois are still part of our team and have made impressive careers since then. üöÄ

SENNEBOGEN Launches Green Steel Material Handler ‚ôªÔ∏è

üåç Steel production alone is responsible for 7% of global CO‚ÇÇ emissions‚ùó

At SENNEBOGEN, we are committed to sustainability ‚Äì not only through energy-efficient machine solutions, but also by using more sustainable materials. That‚Äôs why we now offer machines built with green steel ‚Äì and by "green," we don‚Äôt just mean our signature color. üü¢

üçÉ "Green steel" refers to CO‚ÇÇ-reduced, more sustainable steel production, which we can offer now in partnership with salzgitterag and its subsidiary deumu_gmbh (Deutsche Erz- und Metall-Union GmbH). Compared to conventional steel production, this enables CO‚ÇÇ savings of more than 70%.

Our very first green steel machine is one of our newly launched 40 t SENNEBOGEN 830 G material handlers, a model already known for its exceptional efficiency. With green steel we are cutting up to 20 tons CO‚ÇÇ emission per machine.

SENNEBOGEN now offers comprehensive implementation of this option for all models on request.

Die Mosel, mit einer L√§nge von 544 km der zweitl√§ngste Nebenfluss des Rheins, spielt eine entscheidende Rolle als internationale Wasserstra√üe. 28 Staustufen erm√∂glichen den Binnenschiffen ein reibungsloses Vorankommen.
